pageContext.desc: Written from the Oklahoma Territory, the Southwest, and the Dakotas, regarding his commissioned series of portraits of prominent Indian Chiefs.
pageContext.category: Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection; Indians of North America; Letters (Correspondence)

pages.transcription:
[Hotel Brewster]
[San Diego, California] April 6th 09.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I am on my way
to the Campo Indians
who live in the mountains
in Southern California.
I have never been to the Campo
Indians and very few of
them are left.
They live 60 miles from
here by Stage.
Mr Lummis has written a
good deal on the Campo
Indians they are a poor
lot, the trouble is I am told
their land is very poor.
They make fine baskets
soon as I am through with
them I will return to
Los Angeles and do some
work there for a while.

I will have to go to Oklahoma
to finish up the 270 red
drawings, there are several
tribes there that I have not
been to.
You can address me to
General Delivery. Los Angeles.
California.
Your affectionate
nephew.
Elbridge

Campo Calif.
April 9th 09.
My dear Uncle Ed
I am getting good
types here but it is
hard to get these Indians
to sit for portraits as
hard up as they are
These Indians are
scattered around on
this reservation only
a few living in one
place. They are a very
poor lot as a rule 
and most of them

are hungry most of
the time. I was at one
place and I never saw
such a poor lot of
Indians, they did 'nt
even have enough blankets
to keep them warm. The
trouble is they live on 
such poor land.
They seem willing enough
to work on their land
such as it is, now and
then some Indian has
a few rods of fairly
good land and he
does fairly well, that
is he has plenty to eat
but as a rule they 
are a mighty poor lot

of Indians.
The white people around
here own the best land
and the Campo Indians
live as a rule among
the rocks.
You can address
me to General Delivery
Los Angeles.
Calif.
Your affectionate
nephew.
Elbridge.

Los Angeles.
Calif.
April 20th 09.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I am sending
you today by W.F. Ex
ten red drawings of
the Campo Indians
This makes 184
red drawings I have
sent you since Feb 5th
and I have 86 more
red drawings to make to
complete the 270.
You can send a check

to H.D. Crumb Harvard
Bank Harvard Ill's.
to place to my credit
This makes $1004.00
worth of red drawings
I have sent you so far.
You can address me
to 736 1/2 S. Hill St.
Los Angeles
California
Your affectionate
nephew.
Elbridge.

214 Desmond Street
Elkins, West Virginia 
February 25, 1946 
Dear Mr. Burbank:
Your wonderful picture of 
Andy arrived in fine shape
and now my only worry is 
to find a suitable frame for 
it. Do you think a plain black? 
one would be be too unclear for 
a baby's picture, or what 
would you suggest? 
Everyone, including myself, 
is quite thrilled over the 
drawing, and you can't ima-
gine how proud I am of 
it. I shall keep it always
and I know Andy will be 
proud of it, too. When he 
gets old unclear to realize 
the value of such a drawing. 
I hope you got the money 
and everything O.K. That is 
one will? I certainly want to mark

paid? in my books! 
Poor Louise? has been sick 
she can hardly stand to do 
her teaching, so I have been 
doing all the work since
I came home. But I enjoy 
it more than formerly?. Just
keeping house? for two isn't
unclear, although I will have 
to start in on some 
general house cleaning soon.
She was as badly disa-
ppointed as I, when Andy 
didn't get to come home. About
2 hours before we were to start, I got a telegram not
to come, after all. She and 
Andy are the very best of buddies, and you have strong 
competition there, Mr. BurbankÂ !
But she is wonderful to 
him, and he adores his 
Aunt Louise?. 
I could go on and on about 
Andy, because he is so sweet
don't you think he has an

expressive face, Mr. Burbank?
and he is very intelligent - (do 
all parents say that??!!) but 
I'll bet you would really en-
joy a visit with him + us. 
I don't suppose you could afford to do any more sketches 
at that low rate, for several 
of my friends were interested; 
but I didn't encourage them, 
because I realized that you made it for me because we 
are good friends. 
I certainly do appreciate 
your fine work, and many 
many thanks. I hope you 
are staying well, and unclear 
write soon. 
your friend always, 
Pudgie?

Sunday Afternoon
March 31, 1946
Dear Mr. Burbank 
Your very welcome letter 
came yesterday. I was hoping 
that there would be a letter
from you. 
I am glad to hear that you are looking and feeling so well. 
It really is wonderful to live 
such a long useful life. I 
think people who are happy 
and who try to make others
happy live longer than other 
people. there are very few
people in the world who 
have made so many people 
happy as you have. Many 
people who have wonderful 
gifts, like your gift for 
painting and drawing are very 
selfish. All most of them 
seem to care for is the fame and money they can 
get from their work. You 
have done so much good

and made so many people 
happy as you have gone
along. 
Do you have any more 
of the circulars? about your 
book with your picture 
and the short article about 
you? If you have, please, 
may I have some more
of them? Mine are all gone.
When I give a new unclear 
collector one of yours unclear 
prints or past cards he 
or she always wants to 
know about you so I send 
them all of your book 
circulars?
I am inclosing a dollar. 
Will you please send

me 4 unclear prints? Please 

autograph them for me. My 
unclear collector friends all
enjoy these prints so much 
They are the nicest things unclear
have to give them. 
Yes, I would like to have

I will send you a dollar for 
it when it comes. 
I am very sorry to hear
that Mr. Royce is so very 
ill. I hope that he is
well now. When he is
well, will you begin work
on your new book? I am 
quite anxious for it to be 
published. 
March is not going out 
like a lion today as it 
showered? here? it came in like
a unclear. It could storm 
before midnight, but I don't 
believe that it will. It is 
such a lovely spring - like 
day outside. The lawns are 
getting pretty. Some people 
have already mowed their 
lawns. the fruit trees are blooming. 
I am glad that your

friends drop in to see you

after. A girl friend of mine 
was just married recently. 
She and her husband are

going to live in San Francisco. 
They are going out there in 
a few weeks. I'll ask her 
to call at the Mary? hotel to 
see you. 
I hope that this finds 
you well and happy. 
With love, 
Davie?

Ganado Mission
Ganado, Arizona
May 12, 1946 
Mr. E. A. Burbank 
Hotel Mant?
San Francisco 
California 
Dear Mr. Burbank: 
I am another member of the Burbank 
family, born in Pipestone, Michigan, 
daughter of Charles Harner? Burbank. 
In our family we have a book giving 
the genealogy of the Burbank family. In it 
is your name, listed as a painter of Indian pictures.
When I came here more than three years
ago I was very much interested in your
paintings at Hubbell's Trading Post. Whenever 
I called on Mrs. Goodman and her daughter
Mrs. Eckles, there I always liked to see 
the paintings of "my cousin," Mr. Burbank. 
Besides the pictures of the Indians, I also 
liked the pictures of fruit which you painted. 
I am especially fond of the picture of blackberries
for they look so very natural - good enough to eat. 
In our history book at school there are two of 
your pictures of Indians. 
I would be glad to hear from you. 
I'm a friend of Miss A?. Van Polen. 
Sincerely, 
Erma? unclear Burbank.

214 Diamond Street
Elkins, West Virginia 
Dear Mr. Burbank, 
School closed today, and I am 
too tired to think or move. We 
had our commencement exercises
last evening. It was beautiful, 
but so much work. Instead 
of a regular speaker we have 
a pageant. The children in 
the graduating class put on the 
pageant. That takes hours and 
hours of work. We had 172 in 
our graduating class. 
Today I finished up my reports
and completed all of my work. 
It was five o' clock when I 
left the school building. 
I'm going to rest a while
and try to get caught up with 
my correspondence. 
Our weather bureau? says 
that we are to have some 
summer weather now. Almost
all of May has been cold
and rainy. Sunshine will be

unclear, unclear
May 15, 1946
Dear Mr. Burbank - 
Hello there, how are you?
I was very surprised and 
very pleased to get the nice 
picture, thank you very much.
It is certainly pretty and 
I like it a lot. Mom framed 
it for me and now I am 
going to hang it up in my 
room. 
I have some news for 
you I was married in 
March to a very nice boy 
from Los Angeles. He was
stationed up here on one 
of the Islands but is out 
of the service now and 
working here in unclear.
I know you would like 
him and hope you will be 
able to meet him some day 
soon.

-2-
How is the weather down 
there? It has been quite hot 
up here for the past two?
weeks so guess we are in 
for a real hot summer. 
Well Mr. Burbank I am 
out of news for tonight so 
will close for this time. 
Thanks again from Russ and 
I for the lovely picture. 
Mr. Harwell? + mom send 
there regards . 
Sincerely, 
Ann

Mr E.A. Burbank 
San Francisco, Calif
Dear Sir, 
I have seen some 
of your paintings at 
Hubbles? Trading Post 
not far from here, and 
think they are fine. 
I wonder if you have any paintings for 
sale at unclear. If so 
will you please let 
me know what the 
prices are. 
Miss Erma J. Burbank 
is a friend of mine 
here at Ganado? mission 
and I would like
to get a painting for
her for Christmas - one 
that is not expensive. 
(over)

thanking you for the 
information I remain 
yours truly 
(Miss) Allie Van Polen

May 31, 1946
Dear Mr. Burbank
Many thanks 
for the Lincoln unclear
also the Will? Rogers 
picture + poem +? 
the comical one. You 
are doing fine work
Best wishes 
Pat Mulker?

Saturday Afternoon 
June 1, 1946
Dear Mr. Burbank, 
Two letters today from you, and 
both of them began "Dear Miss
Gaddin? Please, I like "Davie?
much better. 
This is our first day of June
and we are having rain. I do hope 
this doesn't mean that we are 
going to have rain all during the 
month of June. 
Please excuse this violent 
violet color ink. I know that 
it isn't very good taste, but I 
put it in my pew? for some 
special writing last night and 
my other ink is down home. 
Our church had its mother
and daughter Banquet last night.
It was very nice. One of the 
social affairs that I enjoy 
but I'm glad that it is over. 
I usually have to help get ready 
for it. This year I helped make 
the programs and favors. The

page - 2
crocheted unclear nut baskets of purple 
unclear paper for the favors. They 
were very pretty. 
I'm going to see if I can find 
some other ink. This isn't doing
right. 
Well, I've located some "South 
Sea Blue", It is almost as 
bad as the purple. Which do 
you think is worse? Ha?
Yes, my friend Mrs. Philips 
is a very charming person. You 
would like her very much. We 
have been the best of friend
since grade school days. She is
perhaps the best girl friend that 
I have ever had. 
I'm looking forward to the 
latest Arizona Highways. You 
ask what I do with them. I 
have saved all of them. They
are so pretty! 
Our family doctor usually spends his vacation in the 
West. He usually spends part of it in Arizona unclear

page - 4 
My Grandmother use to make 
the most delicious raspberry 
short cake. I have been 
eating raspberry jam and 
country butter since I have 
been here. We had warm 
biscuits with them one evening. 
Your dog pictures are lovely 
I cannot imagine anyone not liking 
them. I should think that 
they would like your pictures
even if they did not like dogs. 
I think that all of your 
pictures are wonderful no 
matter what you paint. I 
only wish that I had more 
money to buy them. My last 
check was for only four 
days. You see, I missed 
sixteen days. We do not have 
any sick leave, so I lost all
of that. I'm going to have 
to be very? saving or I will 
not have enough to do me 
this summer. 
I will just have to do with

page - 3
wife if Arizona is really as 
beautiful as the magazine 
pictures. She said that it is. 
I'm returning the copy 
of your letter to the Arizona 
Highways. I'm sure that they 
will be glad to get it
How is your lovely California 
weather? My friend wrote that she found it quite chilly. She 
said that her fur coat felt good. I think that this rainy 
weather must be all over 
the United States. We surely 
are having our share of it here. 
I do hope that we can get 
the coal strikes settled soon. 
People seem to think that the
Railroad strike is settled. Did 
it affect Dick's work? 
The "funny cards" are really 
funny. We have had several 
good laughs over them I also 
enjoyed the latest bunch of 
humorous clippings. 
You write about eating 
raspberries unclear

page 5
out a lot of things. I really do not 
care. I'm just so glad to be 
getting well again. 
Please do not work so hard. 
It really isn't any wonder that 
you get so tired you work 
such long hours. If you will 
take care of yourself, and not 
work so hard you will be 
doing grand work for many 
years yet. 
Just as soon as we are 
allowed to mail packages again,
I will return the Indian? Houses
that I have not sold. One 
of my friends would like two 
of the small paintings of some 
scenes She especially liked the 
one you sent me of "Spring time 
in the Desert". It is so pretty 
with the lovely flowers. Does 
it take very long to do those? 
Will you do her two something 
like that? She wants them 
something alike so that she can

hang them as a set. She wants

Page 6 Page 6
If the museum does have 
the painting The story of Emancipation 
let me know. You know how
very interested I am in any thing 
about Mr. Lincoln, and 
especially this wonderful 
painting of yours. 
Yes, Pudgie? and her husband 
are living with me. It is 
almost impossible to get any 
place to live here. She still
collects pigs and buttons, but 
she doesn't have as much 
time for them since baby 
Andy came. 
Your unclear Roger cards are 
grand! Yes, I have seen all 
of his moving pictures. He
was really a great man. 
You said that you had 
bought a yellow rose for your
room. I like roses of all kinds, 
but yellow roses are my favorite. 
Roses are blooming now. This is always such a lovely

Page 7
My uncle and family plan on 
returning tomorrow. I will be 
very glad. There isn't much to 
do here, and there are so many 
things that I could be doing
if I were home. 
I have not heard from your
friend who is interested in Lincoln,
but I hope that he will write. I am
always glad to hear from anyone 
who is interest in Lincoln. 
This is getting to be quite 
a long letter so it had better 
stop. 
Lots of love, 
Davie

June 8th 1946
Mr. E.A. Burbank  
Hotel unclear 
San Francisco, California 
I have your letter of June 3rd on hand and 
contents sealed. Please be advised that to 
date I have never received a picture by you
of Abraham Lincoln. I left? Dayton very shortly 
after you sent me a letter telling me that if I send you 
500  you would draw us a picture. Since then I have 
heard nothing. 
I am visiting the post office tonight in Dayton
to? see if they are holding any mail, because they 
did have a forwarding address. I have moved 
several times since, only to find myself finally 
located in this town. 
I have not written Miss Goddin? as I have 
been very busy. I wrote her only unclear unclear 
evening. I've got to send her some pictures I 
promised her. 
I shall let you know the results as soon 
as I have word as I am very anxious to get one of 
your drawings. I have seen duplicates of them +
think they are wonderful. 
Yours truly, 
Donald? unclear
3106 Biddle? Ave 
unclear Michigan

pageContext.title: E.A. Burbank letters, 1909, 1945-1947
